title: Custom Type in the Auto Industry: Where Does It Come From?
content: Every car's logo seems to use custom type, and pretty cool type at that. Where is all this original work coming from? Are designers from major foundries commissioned? Then why aren't they making fonts this cool? And can anyone think of another industry that generates as much custom type?
author: pdxuser

comments.content:
Can you show us some examples of car logos you like? Maybe they just look so much cooler, because they are in chrome and not in black and white? ;-)

When it comes to those script-like car logos, it makes a big difference to make ONE word look good or to make a typeface, because of the problem of all the letter ligatures. I am just in the process of making a font inspired by car logos, and I can tell you it's not easy. Without the relatively new OpenType technology it would be impossible at all. So I learned pretty quick, why there are not much fonts in this style.

Ralf

\> Then why aren’t they making fonts this cool?

Well, it is a lot easier to make six or eight letters "cool" than an entire set of glyphs. With a font you might have to change the shape of one letter to provide visual consistency with others.

Basically, there is a big difference between creating a logo and creating a font.

I love type on cars. 5-6 years ago i walked around Oslo for a couple of hours and took some [snapshots](http://web.archive.org/web/20141005225210/http:/www.melkeveien.no/magnus/cartypo.pdf) for an article i wrote. One beer to the first one to spot my old car!  
I have to add that the snaps are of both good and bad examples.

_"Mr. Ford's right-hand man, Harold Wills, earned money printing business cards in his teens, so when Henry was looking for a logo in 1903 he dusted off his old John Bull printing set. The typeface was the one he used for his own visiting cards."_

_why aren’t they making fonts this cool?_

They are, but you have to know where to look.

_another industry that generates as much custom type?_

It's not custom type. but custom logos. Retail, fashion, architecture, music. And the publishing industry, of course.

Porsche has all it's own fonts. It has the script it has been using for years and no one has ripped off or digitized. It has even taken Franklin Gothic and put it's own spin on it, so that when you see a genuine Porsche ad it is in genuine Porsche Franklin Gothic.

Land Rover has been using fonts that the public can buy. Last year they switched their body copy to a font that is sold in England, and well, I couldn't see spending the money they were asking. (I've put it in Eurostile, and Y&R have been okay with the results -- because we are getting paid.)

Many of the cars have fonts that look original, but they have been modified to get the "logo type look."

It remind me of publishing -- during the days when every titled was handlettered. Only, they weren't all handlettered -- so many were handtailored. A swash added here, a line deleted there - and voila - a great looking three word title...

"So, what font is that?"

That is "Align", one of my own type designs.

Interestingly, the American and Japanese automakers (Honda, Toyota, Ford, etc.) tend to create custom wordmarks for every model. The European makers (BMW, Mercedes, VW) avoid this and have a standard typeface for their entire line.

Dalton Maag made the new BMW fonts for the Corp and the car dashboard.
